American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the falling Highway system , and believe to have found the solution in a small black box that can be found in each car ’ s armature board .

The equipment recording every kilometre driven and reporting the information to the authorities is at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and federal planning offices to revise the obsolete system for financing US roads .
The usually boring road planning area has suddenly created an intensive debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have associated with environmental groups and are in favour of the government using the small boxes to record the kilometres – and perhaps even where they have been driven – and then using the information to calculate tax modest .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and raises a number of concerns about data protection .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how they can switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of drivers have already tested tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .

“ It ’ s nothing we can only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn. of Governments , who plans to record miles for all California drivers in the federal state from 2025 onwards .

The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes that pay US Americans at the tap , is defaulting .

Far planets , gravitational waves or black holes - experts from the European Space Agency must now agree on two major projects that they want to start over the next few years .
30 proposals were available , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .

The choice is difficult : should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origin of cosmos ?
Or are you looking for similar planets , and thus perhaps discoverlife ?
These are the questions that the European Space Agency Esa is responsible for .
For their Cosmic Vision program , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that are intended to make significant progress in research .
The budget for such ' L missions ' is around EUR 1 billion each .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
Earlier in September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were debated , five of them have now come to the closer election .
Numerous bodies examined the proposals , took a look at them .
A final decision will be taken by the scientific committee in the next few days .
In total , four major questions have been chosen by the Esa , to which the missions of the Cosmic Vision program initiated in 2007 are to be found .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact processes involved in the emergence of stars from large gas clouds - and thus also the emergence of planets circulating these stars - are still in proverbial darkness .
A big infrared elescope in all could penetrate this dark .
And if a star planet possesses under what circumstances can life emerge there ?
In 2017 , the ' Cheops ' space telescope is to launch this issue , which will examine more closely 500 already known planet systems in our surroundings .
However , the possibilities are limited , cheops are a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could illustrate similar planets and even analyse the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This issue , too , is supposed to provide an insight into the conditions for the emergence of life .
The magnetic activity of a star plays an important role , as well as the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation from it with the planet system .
In our solar system these processes can be examined in an exemplary manner .
With the Solar Orbiter , Esa has already approved a M class mission ( there is a budget of about half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe will start in 2017 and watch closely the surface and activity of the sun .
Jupiter and his moons are of great interest to the researchers .
They want to find out what role the Giant Planet played in the development of the solar system .
For this , the Esa provides the first of the three L-missions of the Cosmic Vision programme .
The song " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to begin its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reaches Jupiter and is supposed to examine the atmosphere of the planet , as well as the icy moon Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .

Welltal offers many opportunities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature we know are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that could give physicists the way to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How did the universe emerge and what is it like ?
13.7 billion years ago , our cosmos were created by the big bang .

Besides the frequent material that consists of stars , planets and living beings as we do , there is dark matter whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxy clusters together , and dark energy , which accelerates the expansion of space .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first seconds of the Big Bang , nor do they know what dark matter and dark energy are .
With " Euclid " , the Esa has already approved a M mission , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is intended to examine the distribution of the matter in the universe for the first time throughout the sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of Dark Material and Dark Energy .
